awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns the analysis of the patterns that emerge when a simple geometric construction is repeated indefinitely. An example of a geometric problem having to do with the arrangement of shapes in space is: If one (endlessly) glues together equilateral triangles so that 7 triangles go around each vertex, is it possible to embed the resulting surface in 3-dimensional space?  An example of a problem having to do with geometric shapes in the plane is to determine the possible shapes swept out by the path of a frictionless ball as it rolls (endlessly) around the inside of a polygonal table and bounces off the sides. Such processes occur both in nature and in a purely abstract mathematical context, and often produce mysterious, intricate, and beautiful patterns. These processes have connections to number theory, geometry, and physics. This research project studies these processes via numerical simulation to generate hypotheses that are subsequently confirmed or disproved via rigorous mathematical justification.

Speaking more technically, the principal investigator will continue investigations into geometric dynamics, concentrating on polytope exchange transformations and outer billiards. One common theme in this work is the construction of higher dimensional compactifications of non-compact low-dimensional dynamical systems. Another common theme is the appearance of renormalization phenomena. In the situation of interest, one has a fiber bundle where the base space is the parameter space and each fiber is a polytope exchange transformation based on the parameter it lies over. The goal is then to find an auxiliary transformation of the base space which relates the dynamics at the fiber over one point to the dynamics of the fiber over the image of the point under the transformation. For instance, this seems to happen when one studies the symbolic dynamics of a process, and this project aims to find a general theory for this. The principal investigator will also study a number of geometric iterations, such as the pentagram map, a projectively natural map on the space of polygons that is related to integrable systems and cluster algebras. Finally, the principal investigator plans to attack a number of longstanding unsolved problems in geometry, such as the square peg conjecture.

por.por_cntn:
During the period of this award I continued to study various

problems in geometry and dynamical systems.  I made

progress in three main directions.  I will talk about

each of these in turn.   

 

First, I considered the combinatorial properties of outer

billiards on polygons,. Outer billiards is a game similar to ordinary

billiards, except that the ball travels around the outside

the polygonal table, glancing off the corners according to

the following rule.  A person walking from the current location

of the ball to the next location would move on a line

segment, keeping the table to the right,  so that a corner of

the table lies at the exact center of the line segment.

When one moves from position to position, generally

circulating around the table clockwise, one

records the sequence of corners encountered.

For my first project I construced a kind of model which

predicts which vertices are encountered, depending on

the shape of the polygon and the starting point, when the

polygon is a quadrilateral.   My model reveals a kind

of fractal nature to the sequences, depending on the

number theory associated to the coordinates of the

polygon vertices.

 

Second, I considered how five particles will arrange themselves

on the sphere so as to minimize their total potential energy

when it is computed with respect to a power law.  Some

experimental work done about 40 years ago  by Melnyk

Knopf and Smith suggested that when the exponent of

the power law is less than about 15.05, the answer should

be the triangular bi-pyramid and then the answer changes

to a pyramid-with-square base for larger power law exponents.

This phenomenon is a simple example of a phase change

in physics or chemistry.   Through a combination of

theoretical arguments and computer assisted proof, I

rigorously established the existence of this phase change.

 

Third, I studied problems related to the famous Toeplitz

square peg conjecture, which asserts that one can always

find 4 points contained in any continuous loop in the plane

which make the vertices of a square.  Such a square would

be called an inscribed square.  Relatedly,  a rectangle inscribed

in a continuous loop would be a collection of four points in

the loop which make the vertices of the rectangle. I proved that, for

any continuous loop in the plane, all but at most 4 points

are vertices of an inscribed rectangle.  This result does

not solve the square peg conjecture, but it shows that

inscribed rectangles are very common in continuous loops.
